facts.text: Writ Petition No. 2053 of 1973 filed in Original Jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 2053 of 1973.

facts.text: Petition under Article 32 of the Constitution of India

anchor.surface_text: Petition under Article 32 of the Constitution of India, Shiv Pujan Singh, for the petitioner.

facts.text: Shiv Pujan Singh is the petitioner

anchor.surface_text: India, Shiv Pujan Singh, for the petitioner.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by RAY, C.J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by RAY, C.J.

facts.text: Petitioner challenges order of detention dated 15 March 1973

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner in a writ petition under Article 32 of the Constitution challenges the order of detention dated 15 March, 1973.

facts.text: Order of detention issued in exercise of powers under sub-section 1 read with sub-section 2 of section 3 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act

anchor.surface_text: The order is in exercise of the powers companyferred by sub- section  1  read with sub-section  2  of section 3 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act hereinafter referred to as the Act directing the petitioner to be detained.

facts.text: Order of detention directs the petitioner to be detained

anchor.surface_text: ...the Act directing the petitioner to be detained.

facts.text: Petitioner challenges order on ground that authority must fix period of detention after examining circumstances

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner challenges the order on the ground that it is the duty of the authority to fix the period of detention after carefully examining the circumstances requiring detention.

facts.text: Petitioner submits authorities bodily lifted section fixing maximum period without applying mind

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner submits that the authorities haye bodily lifted the section fixing the maximum period without applying their mind as to the period of detention.

facts.text: This Court in Fagu Shaw etc. v. The State of West Bengal I.R. 1974 S.C. 613 held maximum period in section 13 of the Act valid

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Fagu Shaw etc. v. The State of West Bengal I.R. 1974 S.C. 613 held that the maximum period mentioned in section 13 of the Act as amended by section 6 d  of the Defence of India Act, 1971- is a companystitutionally valid provision.

facts.text: Section 13 states maximum period of detention is 12 months from date of detention or until expiry of Defence of India Act whichever later

anchor.surface_text: That section states that the maximum period for which any person can be detained in pursuance- of any detention which has been companyfirmed under section 12 shall be 12 months from the date of detention or until the expiry of the Defence of India Act whichever later.

facts.text: Defence of India Act 1971 amends section 13 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: ...section 13 of the Act as amended by section 6 d  of the Defence of India Act, 1971- is a companystitutionally valid provision.

facts.text: Court construed section 13 valid with reference to Article 22(7)(b) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: This Court companystrued section 13 of the Act to be valid with ,reference to Article, 22 7  b  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Order of detention in present case does not suffer from any constitutional infirmity

anchor.surface_text: The order of detention in the present case does number suffer from any companystitutional infirmity.
The authorities have applied their mind.

facts.text: Authorities have detained for the maximum period mentioned in the statute

anchor.surface_text: The authorities have detained for the maximum period mentioned in the, statute.
The petition is dismissed.

issues.text: Whether the authorities bodily lifted the section fixing the maximum period of detention without applying their mind as to the period of detention, instead of fixing the period after carefully examining the circumstances requiring detention

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner challenges the order on the ground that it is the duty of the authority to fix the period of detention after carefully examining the circumstances requiring detention. The petitioner submits that the authorities haye bodily lifted

issues.text: Whether section 13 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act as amended by section 6 of the Defence of India Act, 1971 provides for a constitutionally valid maximum period of detention

anchor.surface_text: section 13 of the Act as amended by section 6 d  of the Defence of India Act, 1971- is a companystitutionally valid provision. That section states that the maximum period for which any person can be detained in pursuance- of any detention which has been companyfirmed under section 12 shall be 12 months from the date of detention or until the expiry of the Defence

issues.text: Whether the maximum period of detention under Article 22(7)(b) can be fixed with reference to the duration of an emergency and whether such period is indefinite

anchor.surface_text: This Court companystrued section 13 of the Act to be valid with ,reference to Article, 22 7  b  of the Constitution. The maximum period under Article 22 7  b  can be fixed with reference to the duration of an emergency The expiry of the Defence of India Act is dependent upon the revocation of emergency. The duration of maximum period of detention with reference to an event like the cessation of the period of emergency is number indefinite.

holdings.text: the maximum period mentioned in section 13 of the Act as amended by section 6 d  of the Defence of India Act, 1971- is a companystitutionally valid provision

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Fagu Shaw etc. v. The State of West Bengal I.R. 1974 S.C. 613 held that the maximum period mentioned in section 13 of the Act as amended by section 6 d  of the Defence of India Act, 1971- is a companystitutionally valid provision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows binding precedent from this Court's decision in Fagu Shaw upholding constitutional validity of section 13.

holdings.text: section 13 of the Act to be valid with ,reference to Article, 22 7  b  of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: This Court companystrued section 13 of the Act to be valid with ,reference to Article, 22 7  b  of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior decision of this Court construed section 13 as constitutionally valid under Article 22(7)(b).

holdings.text: The maximum period under Article 22 7  b  can be fixed with reference to the duration of an emergency The expiry of the Defence of India Act is dependent upon the revocation of emergency

anchor.surface_text: The maximum period under Article 22 7  b  can be fixed with reference to the duration of an emergency The expiry of the Defence of India Act is dependent upon the revocation of emergency.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 22(7)(b) permits maximum detention period linked to emergency duration; Defence of India Act expiry tied to emergency revocation.

holdings.text: The duration of maximum period of detention with reference to an event like the cessation of the period of emergency is number indefinite

anchor.surface_text: The duration of maximum period of detention with reference to an event like the cessation of the period of emergency is number indefinite.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Period tied to emergency cessation is definite as emergencies have finite duration.

holdings.text: The order of detention in the present case does number suffer from any companystitutional infirmity

anchor.surface_text: The order of detention in the present case does number suffer from any companystitutional infirmity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies valid section 13 and Article 22(7)(b) to facts of this detention order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows authorities considered relevant circumstances before issuing detention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Detention conforms to maximum period permitted by constitutionally valid statute.
